componenttext: Perfect. And then just jumping back to the international, Marc. You gave some color on the U.K. Can you talk about some other geographies both from a -- either contribution in the quarter or new pipeline prospects that may stick out to you with regards to the last quarter?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, relative to the globe, I think our opportunities very much mimicked the economic conditions of the very -- of the specific countries. So Western Europe, challenging economic conditions. They're not necessarily spending a lot. They're looking
componenttext: Yes. I mean, relative to the globe, I think our opportunities very much mimicked the economic conditions of the very -- of the specific countries. So Western Europe, challenging economic conditions. They're not necessarily spending a lot. They're looking at new projects relative to healthcare IT. We see interests. The beginning of interest and the beginning of looking to do some types of procurements, but the money to fund those isn't there yet. I think on the flip side, we look at areas such the Middle East, Australia and Canada where the economies are doing fairly well. And we see some significant uptick and opportunities in those locations. So I think our global business will tend to very much follow kind of the economic trends that those countries are incurring. Our technology is going to be on the early WishList when they get to a point when they can start spending again. But right now, I'd say that the ones that are doing well are places where we're seeing a lot of opportunity.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: I guess, Zane, first, a couple on the device resale business. Obviously, that's a hot topic. Would you say that the customers that you're dealing with and the types of equipment that you're reselling, that's it's broad enough and diverse enough that you comfortably expect this level of business to continue and to grow from here each quarter?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jamie, we're seeing -- the demand looks very strong. I think we're actually still relatively new in the relationship around the CareFusion side of that. And we've continued to grow that, and we were seeing a good momentum there. And I think there is more
componenttext: Jamie, we're seeing -- the demand looks very strong. I think we're actually still relatively new in the relationship around the CareFusion side of that. And we've continued to grow that, and we were seeing a good momentum there. And I think there is more and more demand for those types of devices as we move forward.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Was it just a matter of time that caused it to really take off recently? Or was there any other dynamic that was in play?
componenttext: Was it just a matter of time that caused it to really take off recently? Or was there any other dynamic that was in play?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jamie, this is Marc. I think some of these relationships -- this is fairly new stuff for us. And it's not limited to a relationship with CareFusion. There's broad strength across a lot of the devices, especially when we bring in the iBus platform, the con
componenttext: Jamie, this is Marc. I think some of these relationships -- this is fairly new stuff for us. And it's not limited to a relationship with CareFusion. There's broad strength across a lot of the devices, especially when we bring in the iBus platform, the connectivity engine that we can provide. So you've got Smart Rooms. You've got all these other bunching of technology. In fact, our RxStation cabinets are doing very well in the marketplace. So it's a little bit of -- when you have our position with a client, they trust us. They know that they put their -- they're counting on us to get their automation right, and that makes it much easier for us to resell technology. We are able to resell technology that, that company stand-alone would have a difficult time selling into that client. So I think we're leveraging our relationship we built up over a number of years, but it's pretty broad. And I'd say from a demand standpoint, clearly, Q4 looks strong. It will probably have some level of strong quarters here, strong quarter there. There's going to be some variability just because of the nature of the business. What we'll try to do is, based on our forecast meetings that we do every quarter, give you a view as to what we think, and you'll be able to see it kind of from the revenue side.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike. One other comment on that topic. I think the other item that's driving demand as we build out more solutions that take advantage of the technology, our fusion management solution integration of these devices into the medical record. Tha
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike. One other comment on that topic. I think the other item that's driving demand as we build out more solutions that take advantage of the technology, our fusion management solution integration of these devices into the medical record. That's what you're seeing. Acceptance and adoption of those solutions are really enhancing the clinical process. That's why you're seeing the growth in device sales increasing so rapidly.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I appreciate that. Two more quick questions. Marc, on Australia, obviously, a lot of news recently around the potential to do a deal there. Are you assuming anything material in the fourth quarter for that?
componenttext: Okay, and I appreciate that. Two more quick questions. Marc, on Australia, obviously, a lot of news recently around the potential to do a deal there. Are you assuming anything material in the fourth quarter for that?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jamie, normally, when we're doing our guidance for bookings, we don't ever assume there's any large single deal that's going to be a huge contributor. As you know in the past, when we end up being significantly over our guidance, it tends to be driven by
componenttext: Jamie, normally, when we're doing our guidance for bookings, we don't ever assume there's any large single deal that's going to be a huge contributor. As you know in the past, when we end up being significantly over our guidance, it tends to be driven by a couple of large deals happening. I don't think we have, particularly in this Q4 forecast, that is unique kind of compared to Q3 where there's one standout large deal that's in our number.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then real quick, Zane, the Stage 2 decisions, I mean, when do we see those really start, do you think? That's my last question.
componenttext: Okay. And then real quick, Zane, the Stage 2 decisions, I mean, when do we see those really start, do you think? That's my last question.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you're beginning to see those Stage 2 decisions being made, and they will continue on to roll through.
componenttext: I think you're beginning to see those Stage 2 decisions being made, and they will continue on to roll through.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Your next question is coming from the line of George Hill with Citigroup.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Marc, with respect to the physician practice business you had highlighted in the second quarter, net [ph] bookings for the first half of the year that were up 50% where they were versus the first half of last year? Are we at the point yet with respect to
componenttext: Marc, with respect to the physician practice business you had highlighted in the second quarter, net [ph] bookings for the first half of the year that were up 50% where they were versus the first half of last year? Are we at the point yet with respect to the size of this business where you might be able to frame up the size of the physician practice market with some metrics, how many docs, maybe revenue size or contribution bookings in the quarter?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: George, it's still a fairly minor component relative to total bookings and other elements of the business. So that's the good news. It's continued opportunity for us, but it's still -- I still think it's a little early to be focused a lot on those numbers
componenttext: George, it's still a fairly minor component relative to total bookings and other elements of the business. So that's the good news. It's continued opportunity for us, but it's still -- I still think it's a little early to be focused a lot on those numbers for the size that they're contributing to date.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe next one. I have 2 quick follow-ups. Next one is, with respect to the device business, as you guys characterize it now, you've touched on this, I think, in kind of a couple of pieces. But what's the value add of buying it from Cerner?
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe next one. I have 2 quick follow-ups. Next one is, with respect to the device business, as you guys characterize it now, you've touched on this, I think, in kind of a couple of pieces. But what's the value add of buying it from Cerner? And what value are you guys contributing to the device resale process?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mike. The value is that, and many of these devices when they're sold independently, they have their own level of intelligence. But it's not -- that information is not being fed directly into the EMR. And we have capabilities within our architectur
componenttext: This is Mike. The value is that, and many of these devices when they're sold independently, they have their own level of intelligence. But it's not -- that information is not being fed directly into the EMR. And we have capabilities within our architecture to interpret that data and help drive the clinical decision-making process, and our clients recognize it. There's tremendous value connecting the 2 together versus buying the 2 components independently.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And my last one, I don't know if Neal is listening. And if he's not, I'll leave this one for Mike. Everything seems to be going great. As members of the investment community, what are we missing?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Nothing. You guys have figured it all out. Things are quite great.

componenttext: Sounds likely.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: No, I think -- I mean, George, I think things are going well [indiscernible] and feel like strong pipelines of business. We're executing very effectively against that business. And we certainly do our best to try to convey what we see as the future to you guys on a quarterly basis. So it feels pretty good.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is coming from the line of Richard Close with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question is coming from the line of Richard Close with Avondale Partners.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Quick question. ICD-10 more discussion in and around that, can you guys just talk a little bit how you're looking at ICD-10 and the types of opportunities you think you can get off of that transition, please?
componenttext: Quick question. ICD-10 more discussion in and around that, can you guys just talk a little bit how you're looking at ICD-10 and the types of opportunities you think you can get off of that transition, please?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Jeff. Probably at a high level, the one big lever is all of our clients will move towards a common release here, addressing ICD-10 across our entire solution family so one lever for us [ph] kind of independent IC-10 is within the next 12 to
componenttext: Sure, this is Jeff. Probably at a high level, the one big lever is all of our clients will move towards a common release here, addressing ICD-10 across our entire solution family so one lever for us [ph] kind of independent IC-10 is within the next 12 to 14 months will have the majority of our client base all sitting on one single release, which is -- we're pretty excited about from an innovation perspective that we will be able to add some of these new solutions on, such as some of the power chart touch that Mike talked about consistently across the base without having to deal with those variabilities. Inside of both revenue cycle, as well as the medical records process, physician documentation is creating, I'll say, more interest or focus on those areas where coding occurs. It's not only a back-end process around dropping the claim, but it drives things more upstream such as computer-assisted coding. And where we see some of the newer opportunities is moving that coding to actually the point of care, point of decision and get it out of the back office. So that's where working with our clients, we see greater opportunities, but it is creating a lot of activity within the base, which is all good.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and this is Mike. I'll add a couple of additional comments. As Jeff mentioned, it is a significant event that all of our clients will be moving to this release. And the release is -- all the code has already been developed to support the ICD-10 requi
componenttext: Yes, and this is Mike. I'll add a couple of additional comments. As Jeff mentioned, it is a significant event that all of our clients will be moving to this release. And the release is -- all the code has already been developed to support the ICD-10 requirements, and we're fully prepared to...

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Because we have that, and there's countries that do ICD-10 already.
componenttext: Because we have that, and there's countries that do ICD-10 already.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. So it's not new to Cerner. But in doing so, we have a couple of opportunities here. One is to apply the best practices that we've accumulated throughout the years and bring our clients to a higher level of productivity and performance from our appl
componenttext: Right. So it's not new to Cerner. But in doing so, we have a couple of opportunities here. One is to apply the best practices that we've accumulated throughout the years and bring our clients to a higher level of productivity and performance from our applications. And in turn, that will result in probably lower support burdens for organizations, so it will free up capacity to continue to advance our solutions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Do you see any benefit of ITWorks or RevWorks directly from the transition?
componenttext: Do you see any benefit of ITWorks or RevWorks directly from the transition?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I'd say there's a very large opportunity for the services to help our clients, and that's going to come in a number of forms. Or so it could come from a RevWorks, ITWorks type of a model or it could come from our clients contracting with us
componenttext: This is Zane. I'd say there's a very large opportunity for the services to help our clients, and that's going to come in a number of forms. Or so it could come from a RevWorks, ITWorks type of a model or it could come from our clients contracting with us to provide additional services assistance because many of our clients need that kind of help, and we have that expertise and the bench strength to do that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just final question here, Marc. I think you mentioned a 20% growth in license and subs, subscriptions in the quarter, and then the 50% on the technology or the device side. I just want to be clear that those are year-over-year numbers? And
componenttext: Okay. And then just final question here, Marc. I think you mentioned a 20% growth in license and subs, subscriptions in the quarter, and then the 50% on the technology or the device side. I just want to be clear that those are year-over-year numbers? And when we look at the year-over-year change in systems sales, I think it's like $55 million. You would still put a majority of that year-over-year change on the license and subscription, wouldn't you, in terms of the revenue contribution?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we had significant contribution across the kind of the upside. And the revenue portion of that this quarter was tech resale but strong software revenue as well and systems.
componenttext: Yes, we had significant contribution across the kind of the upside. And the revenue portion of that this quarter was tech resale but strong software revenue as well and systems.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Stephen Shankman with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from Stephen Shankman with UBS.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess on the macro environment, it seems like hospitals are tightening their budgets and spending as we go into 2012, although I would add that's not really too apparent in your results so far. So is this a phenomenon where, yes, there might be tighteni
componenttext: I guess on the macro environment, it seems like hospitals are tightening their budgets and spending as we go into 2012, although I would add that's not really too apparent in your results so far. So is this a phenomenon where, yes, there might be tightening their budgets a bit, but IT remains at the top of their pecking order? Any color you can provide as to what you're hearing from your clients would be very helpful.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. IT is absolutely at the top of the list. And there's so many things coming at our clients in terms of changes in the reimbursement and in the Meaningful Use elements that IT stays at the top of that list. And we're actually seeing no degrada
componenttext: This is Zane. IT is absolutely at the top of the list. And there's so many things coming at our clients in terms of changes in the reimbursement and in the Meaningful Use elements that IT stays at the top of that list. And we're actually seeing no degradation from a budget constraint point of view.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and this is Mike. More and more, as our clients are being driven toward quality outcomes, I mean, we -- it's a tremendous focus within Cerner to align our resources to drive that value for our clients. And I think they're more than willing to spend m
componenttext: Yes, and this is Mike. More and more, as our clients are being driven toward quality outcomes, I mean, we -- it's a tremendous focus within Cerner to align our resources to drive that value for our clients. And I think they're more than willing to spend money on technology if it allows them to achieve their clinical quality goals and financial goals.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is coming from the line of Sebastian Paquette from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is coming from the line of Sebastian Paquette from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Zane, I think you mentioned some increasing traction from your key competitors. I was wondering if anything in that bake-off process is changing [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Zane, I think you mentioned some increasing traction from your key competitors. I was wondering if anything in that bake-off process is changing [indiscernible]?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there is a realization of being able to hit the predictable timelines, the ability to get access to data is becoming a much more important element as we move forward and as people look to the realities of what's going to happen on the Medicare rei
componenttext: I think there is a realization of being able to hit the predictable timelines, the ability to get access to data is becoming a much more important element as we move forward and as people look to the realities of what's going to happen on the Medicare reimbursement elements. Those 2 things where it's a predictable outcome, the breadth and depth of solutions, and then the access to that data are so important that we are seeing -- we are starting to see that in turn towards that as we look forward.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. But in general, with the bake-offs of -- for a new contract. Are you starting to see some market share consolidation or actually production in a number of vendors being allowed to sit?
componenttext: Okay. But in general, with the bake-offs of -- for a new contract. Are you starting to see some market share consolidation or actually production in a number of vendors being allowed to sit?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're all different. So it just depends on the situation in terms of what you see and how it's contracted for and the relationships that are out there. So it's situational and much more so than I think there's a marketplace trend. Although clearly, we h
componenttext: They're all different. So it just depends on the situation in terms of what you see and how it's contracted for and the relationships that are out there. So it's situational and much more so than I think there's a marketplace trend. Although clearly, we have shown our capabilities and ability to deliver. And the results that we're seeing from our clients in Meaningful Use upfront are being noticed. And so we are in every conversation as it relates to that. And then there's a situational competitors as you look at the landscape.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. I would also give Mike Nill  and his team a lot of credit for bringing our solutions to a point where they are easy-to-use. We are competitive relative to going against our best competitors from just the look and feel and solution itself. An
componenttext: This is Marc. I would also give Mike Nill  and his team a lot of credit for bringing our solutions to a point where they are easy-to-use. We are competitive relative to going against our best competitors from just the look and feel and solution itself. And that makes it much easier to when you add that to the elements that Zane talked about to be successful.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then last question here [indiscernible] purposes there's been a lot of discussion around infrastructure de-bottleneck of your competitors. I'm wondering if that's actually a key competitive advantage and B [ph], if you actually seeing from your compet
componenttext: And then last question here [indiscernible] purposes there's been a lot of discussion around infrastructure de-bottleneck of your competitors. I'm wondering if that's actually a key competitive advantage and B [ph], if you actually seeing from your competitors not be able to start a sleep [ph]?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the question was basically talking about implementation bottlenecks that some of our competitors have been talking about and whether our ability to install quickly and timely is a benefit.
componenttext: So the question was basically talking about implementation bottlenecks that some of our competitors have been talking about and whether our ability to install quickly and timely is a benefit.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a huge differentiator in terms of being able to get to the speed to value and the predictability, and we have the largest consulting implementation workforce in healthcare. It's core competency of what the team has built. And absolutely, that predict
componenttext: It's a huge differentiator in terms of being able to get to the speed to value and the predictability, and we have the largest consulting implementation workforce in healthcare. It's core competency of what the team has built. And absolutely, that predictability is part of that model and our ability to go deliver with that large and experienced consulting workforce. So you hit one of the big ones on the head.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I understand that you're able to begin implementation. Are you actually seeing your competitors not able to start new contracts?
componenttext: I understand that you're able to begin implementation. Are you actually seeing your competitors not able to start new contracts?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We can't really speak to their ability. We're winning, and we start. I assume when they win, they try to start. We just don't see that happen a lot.
componenttext: We can't really speak to their ability. We're winning, and we start. I assume when they win, they try to start. We just don't see that happen a lot.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your final question is coming from Donald Hooker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your final question is coming from Donald Hooker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you all provided some visibility into 2012. And I -- are you -- kind of when we think about bookings growth going into next year, I'm just trying to map out kind of the growth of the company over a longer period of time. Are we going to see that same k
componenttext: So you all provided some visibility into 2012. And I -- are you -- kind of when we think about bookings growth going into next year, I'm just trying to map out kind of the growth of the company over a longer period of time. Are we going to see that same kind of 25% or 30% kind of component of bookings being long-term in nature? Or is that going to kind of grow over next year? I'm just trying to map out in my head how this plays out kind of longer term.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. I mean, just to be clear, we've had -- kind of our average percent from longer-term bookings in that 29% kind over the last 12 months. Actually, this quarter, 26%. It was a little bit below that. I think it's reasonable to assume we are goin
componenttext: This is Marc. I mean, just to be clear, we've had -- kind of our average percent from longer-term bookings in that 29% kind over the last 12 months. Actually, this quarter, 26%. It was a little bit below that. I think it's reasonable to assume we are going to continue kind of in that range. We expect certainly to see some impact from ITWorks and revenue works and see those deals start to come in, as well as strength in the rest of our businesses. So I don't know that I would grow that percentage significantly, but I think it's going to be one that's going to still kind of hover around the 29% to 30% range as kind of average of quarter-over-quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And bookings continues to grow in your mind next year, sort of in line with revenues?
componenttext: And bookings continues to grow in your mind next year, sort of in line with revenues?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We would expect to see bookings growth. I mean, we don't give -- obviously with this call, we kind of less consensus as our view something we give on a quarterly basis to make sure we can provide the most up-to-date information. But clearly, with the oppo
componenttext: We would expect to see bookings growth. I mean, we don't give -- obviously with this call, we kind of less consensus as our view something we give on a quarterly basis to make sure we can provide the most up-to-date information. But clearly, with the opportunities we see clearly with our enhanced pipeline, we would expect to continue to see strong bookings performance.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Finally, I'll wrap it up with the -- I got to ask the balance sheet question. You have a lot of cash. I know you've sort of talked about how you think about using that going into next year. I mean, any incremental thoughts?
componenttext: Finally, I'll wrap it up with the -- I got to ask the balance sheet question. You have a lot of cash. I know you've sort of talked about how you think about using that going into next year. I mean, any incremental thoughts?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We continue to look at opportunities, to be opportunistic. We think we're starting to see the demarcation between the successful companies going forward and the ones that will be less successful. And I think that's probably becoming more apparent to some
componenttext:
We continue to look at opportunities, to be opportunistic. We think we're starting to see the demarcation between the successful companies going forward and the ones that will be less successful. And I think that's probably becoming more apparent to some of those companies. So there may be opportunity to do an acquisition. That clock is ticking, though. We're getting very close to the point, as we've discussed previously, that, that will not be as attractive to us. We're just go and compete in the marketplace and win deals. And at that point when we make that call, we'll certainly look at what other options we have for that cash up to and including to return to the shareholders at some in some form or fashion. But we're going to continue to look at ways to invest in our business first given the choice. 
I want to thank everybody for being on today. We're very pleased with the results of the quarter, and we look forward to a strong Q4 as well. Now thanks for coming in, and have a good evening. Goodbye.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation in today's call. This does conclude the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have a good day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation in today's call. This does conclude the presentation. You may now disconnect. Have a good day.
